<p><strong>Passenger rail in Europe</strong> has seen limited growth in modal share over the past decade, with very few exceptions, and demand was put under further pressure during the COVID-19 crisis. But there is increasing investment in rail as a sustainable option. The EU has made funding available to support rail infrastructure projects, and countries have committed to projects that will improve and increase passenger rail services to relieve road traffic congestion, reduce emissions, and improve the sector’s digital connectivity.</p>
<p>To ensure this commitment is effective, rail companies and governments may wish to make strategic decisions around where and how to invest, and focus spending on projects that support their desired outcomes. For instance, stakeholders could assess the impact of actions and investments against key drivers of modal share to ensure that capital is spent effectively. And they could leverage enabling factors to avoid costly budget overruns and project delays.</p>
<p>This article explores the macrotrends affecting the sector and examines key drivers that countries and companies could leverage to increase modal share and to secure long-term growth. It also offers options to consider and highlights best practices that stakeholders can adopt to take action and define a strategy for sustained passenger-rail growth.</p>
<h2>Passenger rail is under pressure, but has significant potential for long-term growth</h2>
<p>Rail growth has come under pressure from the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on users. The Community of European Railway and Infrastructure Companies (CER) reported that total revenue for the EU rail sector fell by around €26 billion between 2019 and 2020, and passenger operators accounted for €24 billion of this figure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8bc7bf84-ad84-4eb7-81e1-7deca0635243"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8bc7bf84-ad84-4eb7-81e1-7deca0635243" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Oliver Cuenca, “European rail sector revenues fall €26Bn in 2020,” <em>International Railway Journal</em>, February 4, 2021, railjournal.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Over the same period, many European countries reported a marked decline in passenger kilometers. In Germany, France, Italy, and Spain, passenger kilometers dropped by between 40 and 60 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d749bb0-4863-446c-adc8-a1494c0a95b9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d749bb0-4863-446c-adc8-a1494c0a95b9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Railway transport, Passengers transported, Eurostat, September 21, 2021, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> Revenue losses are likely to continue in the short term as demand is only expected to recover between 2023 and 2025—and costs do not scale back if revenue falls.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="69ef0d49-f204-4bb0-991e-bcdb3809f22b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="69ef0d49-f204-4bb0-991e-bcdb3809f22b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In the Netherlands, The Knowledge Institute for Mobility Policy (KiM) forecasts that rail will reach pre-COVID-19 levels in 2024. See “Public transport and the corona crisis”, KiM, July 9, 2020, kimnet.nl; and the Dutch railway NS indicates that the number of travelers will reach preCOVID-19 levels in 2025. See “NS Jaarcijfers: Maximale inzet in financieel dramatisch jaar 2020,” NS, February 25, 2021, nieuws.ns.nl.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Furthermore, some passenger segments such as commuting and business travel may not fully recover, as demand could be permanently affected by increased remote working. For instance, it is estimated that between 20 and 25 percent of the workforce in advanced economies could work from home between three and five days a week.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9d2f7ec7-f9a9-4db5-afa5-927ac2ed8896"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9d2f7ec7-f9a9-4db5-afa5-927ac2ed8896" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-after-covid-19">The future of work after COVID-19</a>,” McKinsey Global Institute, February 18, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> This represents four to five times more remote work than before the pandemic. McKinsey’s Travel, Logistics & Infrastructure practice estimates that about 20 percent of business travel may not return.</p>
<p>Despite this outlook, several macrotrends such as sustainability, urbanization and population growth position passenger rail as part of the solution for tackling mobility and sustainability issues, and indicate that the sector could achieve long-term growth.</p>
<p>Sustainability is a key transportation factor as Europe seeks to realize its net-zero goals. Rail generates approximately 4 to 6 times less CO2 emissions than travel by car (with an internal combustion engine), depending on the length of the journey.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="03c6b5c4-f06f-4752-807c-6289817f25db"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="03c6b5c4-f06f-4752-807c-6289817f25db" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on a CO<sub>2</sub> comparison tool available at Eco passenger, ecopassenger.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Even compared to electric vehicles, rail has a lower carbon footprint per passenger kilometer, at 6 to 41 grams compared to 46 to 77 grams for electric vehicles.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7d7ebc50-8dcf-4a1e-a61b-e9b525db1fb5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7d7ebc50-8dcf-4a1e-a61b-e9b525db1fb5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Hannah Ritchie, “Which form of transport has the smallest carbon footprint?,” Our World in Data, October 13, 2020, ourworldindata.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Compared to air travel, rail is the also greener option, generating about 10 to 15 times less CO<sub>2</sub> emissions per passenger.</p>
<p>Increasing urbanization and population growth lead to more congestion in cities; rail can help relieve road traffic congestion and reduce air pollution. Urbanization has been steadily increasing in Europe, from approximately 64 percent to 75 percent over the past 50 years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="13f77788-4145-4780-bc54-0e1d69130d81"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="13f77788-4145-4780-bc54-0e1d69130d81" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Urban population (% of total population) – European Union, Word Bank, accessed 21 September, 2021, data.worldbank.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Even though the EU’s population is expected to peak by 2025, several countries, including Sweden, Switzerland, France, Spain, and the Netherlands, are showing positive population growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b96f1b2-5764-44b9-b5a6-7e1654fae143"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b96f1b2-5764-44b9-b5a6-7e1654fae143" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Annual population projection, Eurostat, accessed 21 September, 2021, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As a result of these macrotrends, rail is seen as one of the safest, most innovative, and sustainable modes of transport. This EU-wide support is illustrated by several initiatives: 2021 has been designated as the European Year of Rail, for example, and rail is a central element of Europe’s Sustainable and Smart Mobility Strategy.</p>
<p>But even with this positive sentiment, passenger modal share has shown limited growth over the past decade, levelling off at around 8 percent since 2013.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3f9bc5d8-5913-4c00-aa09-5e578dacecfb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3f9bc5d8-5913-4c00-aa09-5e578dacecfb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Modal split of passenger transport, Eurostat, accessed 21 September, 2021, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> Modal share, however, varies by country (Exhibit 1). Switzerland has the highest modal share of roughly 20 percent. The country increased its modal share by 2.4 percentage points over the past 10 years by investing heavily in the rail network, integrating its ticketing system, and increasing user satisfaction. There’s much other countries can learn from Switzerland’s experiences.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/safe%20smart%20and%20green%20boosting%20european%20passenger%20rails%20modal%20share/svg-european-rail-exhibit-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Modal shares started flattening around 8 percent; Switzerland exhibited the highest absolute growth at over 2 percentage points." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/safe%20smart%20and%20green%20boosting%20european%20passenger%20rails%20modal%20share/svg-european-rail-exhibit-1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Given the macrotrends, and strong European support, this is a good time for all rail stakeholders to reflect on their growth ambitions for the future.</p>
<h2>Rail growth is supported on a European and national level</h2>
<p>The European Union has defined various programs, and made funding available, to support rail as the backbone of the European economy and position it as an important component of the European Green Deal. The Green Deal aims to transform the EU into a resource-efficient and competitive economy and has set a target of net-zero emissions by 2050. Providing more public transport is a key factor for reducing emissions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="78589886-b722-49e9-b1f4-3b43cadc9470"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="78589886-b722-49e9-b1f4-3b43cadc9470" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“A European Green deal: Striving to be the first climate-neutral continent,” European Commission, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The European Commission defined 2021 as the European Year of Rail to help shift passenger and freight transport from road to rail, and to highlight rail as a sustainable, smart and safe means of transport. It also launched the Sustainable and Smart Mobility Strategy which lays the foundation for how the EU transport system can achieve its green and digital transformation and become more resilient to future crises. The strategy includes ambitious targets for rail, such as doubling highspeed rail traffic by 2030 and tripling it by 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="df138db0-8d2f-4a76-aaeb-9d7ed653013c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="df138db0-8d2f-4a76-aaeb-9d7ed653013c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mobility Strategy, European Commission, December 9, 2020, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The EU has provided funding to support the Green Deal and COVID-19 recovery plans. For instance, the Next Generation EU facility and the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) which includes National Recovery and Resilience Plans (NRRPs), together now provide a total budget of €2 trillion. An estimated €86 billion of this funding could be used for rail projects over the next six years (Exhibit 2).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7159d6ed-f27c-45f6-8452-d5e23cb9527e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7159d6ed-f27c-45f6-8452-d5e23cb9527e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis of NRRPs, cohesion data overview, EC Europe, INEA, CEF, CF/ERDF, Horizon Europe, DG and Agencies.</span></span></span></a></span> To illustrate the potential impact of this amount, €86 billion could cover the construction costs for 3,200km of high-speed rail, or the costs of purchasing about 8,000 intercity trains.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eb7d6a18-1a0c-4b9b-8666-0ac6e52f4921"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eb7d6a18-1a0c-4b9b-8666-0ac6e52f4921" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">According to the World Bank, average construction costs for high-speed rail are between $25 million and $39 million per kilometer (€21 million−€33 million per kilometer). Taking the midpoint of the range would allow for 3,200km of high-speed rail at a cost of €86 billion. See “Cost of high speed rail in China one third lower than in other countries”, World Bank, July 10, 2014, worldbank.org; According to de Volkskrant, the cost of ordering 99 Intercity New Generation (ICNG) is €1.1 billion, or €11 million per ICNG. See Peter de Waard, “Kunnen de NS de nieuwe Wespen nog annuleren?”, <em>de Volkskrant</em>, May 2, 2020, volkskrant.nl.</span></span></span></a></span> It is worth noting that not all of this funding would go to rail and infrastructure operators, but would include a variety of stakeholders.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients">Travel, Logistics & Infrastructure Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Travel page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Beyond European funding through the MFF and NRRPs, some countries have already committed to funding at a national level. The Netherlands, for instance, has committed approximately €2.5 billion of its national growth fund to two important projects that will reinforce and expand key transit corridors to relieve congestion and increase rail capacity. The country plans to expand the “Noord-Zuid” metro line in Amsterdam, and expand and modernize the “Oude Lijn” heavy-rail route between The Hague and Rotterdam.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fd1acd5e-cc16-476e-82df-a05d48d6991b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fd1acd5e-cc16-476e-82df-a05d48d6991b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“25 miljard euro uit groeifonds naar spoorprojecten,” Spoorpro, March 9, 2021, spoorpro.nl.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>For some countries, an increase in NRRP funding will have limited impact, while for others it may constitute a significant leap in available funding. For example, in Italy the CAPEX budget of the state-owned rail network, Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane, was €8.1 billion in 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8292cc14-ea0f-4afb-854f-e6e95427acf8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8292cc14-ea0f-4afb-854f-e6e95427acf8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“FS Italiane: 2019 Annual Report,” FS, March 31, 2020, fsitaliane.it.</span></span></span></a></span> An extra €31.4 billion will be made available for infrastructure for sustainable mobility in Italy through the NRRP between 2021 and 2027.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="80a861d9-2614-44b6-8ba0-7f7625fe3dc3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="80a861d9-2614-44b6-8ba0-7f7625fe3dc3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Italian Parliament, Studies–Budget: Italy and the European Union Economic Policy and Public Finance, The National Recovery and Resilience Plan (PNRR), September 23, 2021, temi.camera.it.</span></span></span></a></span> In theory, this could constitute a potential yearly increase in the rail network’s CAPEX budget of around 55 percent, providing opportunities for investments to transfer traffic from road to rail, reduce passenger travel times, improve connections, and enhance the digital transformation of the rail system.</p>
<p>Available funding for the rail sector highlights the importance of decision makers allocating funds to the right projects, and managing projects effectively, to ensure that the sector benefits from an increase in modal share. Stakeholders taking up opportunities to invest would benefit from thinking through their approach to execution and whether enablers of success are in place to limit their risks and avoid budget overruns and inefficient spending.</p>
<h2>What could rail and infrastructure companies that want to act now to increase modal share consider?</h2>
<p>As a first step, companies could map the impact of actions and investments to modal share drivers to ensure that capital is spent effectively and that projects yield the intended benefits. Various successful initiatives have been implemented in Europe that offer guidance on ways to influence rail’s modal share. These range from operational measures, such as real-time monitoring and predictive maintenance, to more commercial measures such as alternative pricing schemes, including budget trains and flat-fee subscriptions.</p>
<p>McKinsey analysis has identified the following five potential broad drivers that companies can leverage to provide better services for passengers and increase modal share:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Time efficiency.</em> The Netherlands provides a good example of providing time-efficient rail travel options that lead to an increase in passenger numbers. The country built a successful regional rail network, “Randstadrail”, by connecting a set of old train tracks and existing tram/metro tracks to create a light rail line between The Hague and Rotterdam. This successfully reduced road traffic and increased the number of rail passengers from 29,000 a day in 2007 to 125,000 a day in 2018.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b0c27114-6f8d-4c16-8726-3b4c8a33bfbf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b0c27114-6f8d-4c16-8726-3b4c8a33bfbf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“RandstadRail nu hét voorbeeld van light rail,” OV Magazine, July 5, 2018, ovmagazine.nl.</span></span></span></a></span> Another approach could be to apply takt-based scheduling to increase efficiency and provide consistent passenger schedules. The Swiss network has centered operations around a takt-based timetable, where trains come together on the hour, and the half-hour, at core stations. Pulse timetabling—where trains come together or “pulse” at 15, 30, or 60-minute intervals—is also used extensively in intercity and regional rail systems in Germany and the Netherlands.</li>
    <li><em>Ease of use.</em> Simplifying ticketing, so that passengers can use one ticket across different modes of transport, can facilitate ease of use and attract customers. The Dutch transport system, for example, introduced multimodal synchronized ticketing with its OV-chipkaart (chip card), that gives passengers convenient access to trains, buses, trams, and even bicycles with just one card. Another example is the Spanish rail operator, Renfe, that recently approved the tender for the development of its proprietary Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) platform called “Renfe-as-a-Service,” which is expected to launch by the end of 2021. This app will allow passengers to purchase tickets for a variety of modes of transport.</li>
    <li><em>Reliability.</em> Advances in technology and digitization are enabling solutions and innovative ways to attract customers by improving rail reliability. Siemens, for example, leveraged real-time monitoring and predictive maintenance to push the high-speed line between Barcelona and Madrid to a 99.9 percent on-time score, while reducing operational costs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="afb69046-ac89-4646-883f-08e9ee0acff7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="afb69046-ac89-4646-883f-08e9ee0acff7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Thanks to predictive maintenance the #Velaro E trains between Barcelona and Madrid run w/ 99.9% availability,” Siemens, November 9, 2016, twitter.com/siemens.</span></span></span></a></span> In Italy, Gruppo Ferrovie dello Stato has been leveraging an innovative monitoring tool that collects real-time information, allowing for effective and timely management of specific events related to railway traffic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ee1f757-4306-4204-99f9-ff4663dccc0c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ee1f757-4306-4204-99f9-ff4663dccc0c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Il Gruppo FS Italiane presenta il nuovo sistema SOI per la digitalizzazione nel monitoraggio della rete ferroviaria,” TTS Italia, November 22, 2019, ttsitalia.it.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition to digitization, the quality and maintenance of the rolling stock and adjacent systems are key underlying levers for improving the predictability of traffic.</li>
    <li><em>Environmental impact.</em> Rail is already one of the most sustainable modes of transport, with more than 90 percent of passenger kilometers in many European countries being provided on electrified tracks.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a203bbad-4927-4e95-b7c1-958901184062"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a203bbad-4927-4e95-b7c1-958901184062" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Deutsche Bahn, Key figures 2019/2020, deutschebahn.com.</span></span></span></a></span> That said, there is further room for improvement through hydrogen or catenary electrification for diesel lines, as only 54 percent of the rail tracks in Europe had been electrified by 2016.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ad397619-8cad-4dfe-a484-d2a7c83da81a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ad397619-8cad-4dfe-a484-d2a7c83da81a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Report from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council, European Commission, February 6, 2019, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> More importantly, companies are switching to green energy. For example, in 2017 the Dutch railway network, NS, became the first in the world to run trains completely on wind energy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2b361b93-aabf-4d8d-8f47-7f39e7b06e2a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2b361b93-aabf-4d8d-8f47-7f39e7b06e2a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Green energy for train, bus and station,” NS, accessed 21 September 2021, ns.nl.</span></span></span></a></span> Hydrogen rail projects have been gaining traction, and many European countries are piloting hydrogen projects or plan to do so. For example, Alstom and Snam have teamed up to develop hydrogen trains in Italy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3c597114-19cf-4c68-ba6f-53c0c720ef95"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3c597114-19cf-4c68-ba6f-53c0c720ef95" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Agreement between Altstom and Snam for the development of hydrogen trains in Italy,” Alstom press release, June 4, 2020, alstom.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Beyond decarbonizing their own emissions, rail companies could also cooperate with suppliers to decarbonize their entire supply chain.</li>
    <li><em>Price of the journey.</em> Price is a major consideration for passengers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="11427616-08d0-4630-a490-6f0188706e80"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="11427616-08d0-4630-a490-6f0188706e80" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Research from the Netherlands shows that while time efficiency and reliability are important to passengers, price is the primaryconsideration See “Verklaring van de ontwikkeling van het ov-gebruik in Nederland over 2005-2016,” The Knowledge Institute for Mobility Policy (KiM), July 19, 2018, kimnet.nl.</span></span></span></a></span> Ouigo, a French low-cost high-speed train service, introduced a budget high-speed train that competes with airlines on price. This SNCF subsidiary has shown steep growth since inception, targeting 25 million passengers in 2020, prior to COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b07a5389-1312-48fd-8254-507508970948"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b07a5389-1312-48fd-8254-507508970948" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">SNCF: Your Global Transport Partner 2020, June 25, 2020, sncf.com.</span></span></span></a></span> In other examples, the City of Vienna introduced a €365 flat fee for a full year of unlimited public transport, leading to a 2 percent modal share increase. And in Germany, VAT on rail travel was reduced from 19 to 7 percent, effectively reducing consumer costs with some fares of 50km or over coming down by around 10 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91e340f8-7622-4dda-b255-271b7481638e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91e340f8-7622-4dda-b255-271b7481638e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew Murphy, “German rail fares go down as part of climate measures,” Transport and Environment, January 16, 2020, transportenvironment.org.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<p>Though all drivers are important, they may not all have the same impact, and this could vary by region.</p>
<p>In addition to the role that individual companies could play, national and European regulatory policies could also help grow rail’s modal share. As a McKinsey article “<a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/navigating-the-eu-rail-market-liberalization">Navigating the EU rail-market liberalization</a>” shows, market liberalization can have a positive impact on passenger demand, pricing, and the offerings available. In Italy, for example, the introduction of Italo NTV in 2012—as part of the commercialization of the long-distance market—led to a 69 percent increase in passenger kilometers between 2011 and 2018. The increase was driven by higher frequency, more connections, and shorter travel times.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ad20ddf-f173-4a80-9fca-5c3bf16ee00f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ad20ddf-f173-4a80-9fca-5c3bf16ee00f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/navigating-the-eu-rail-market-liberalization">The liberalization of the EU passenger rail market: Growth opportunities and new competition</a>,” July 2019, McKinsey & Company.</span></span></span></a></span> It was also underpinned by the combined impact of a modal shift from other forms of transport—such as the reduction of 1 billion passenger kilometers on the Milan-Rome plane route—and the unleashing of strong and previously hidden demand. The French government also introduced various policies that favor train travel instead of air to reduce carbon emissions. For instance, French MPs recently voted to suspend internal flights if the trip could be completed by train within two and a half hours.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f1f6395-c7e5-4c1f-8274-55f59cdeaea7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f1f6395-c7e5-4c1f-8274-55f59cdeaea7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“France to ban some domestic flights where train available,” <em>The Guardian</em>, April 12, 2021, theguardian.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Regulatory policies such as these could play a key role in incentivizing customers and shaping a modal share increase.</p>
<p>Other operators and authorities can learn from Switzerland’s experience as the country with the overall highest modal share in Europe. The country applied rigorous commitment, drove execution, focused on alignment, and invested approximately CHF50 billion to achieve a 20 percent modal share.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="880ce066-f136-4f10-85ff-04b2ad4a1c33"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="880ce066-f136-4f10-85ff-04b2ad4a1c33" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Investment funds for rail infrastructure in Switzerland along various expansion programs: CHF 30.5 billion from 1998-2018 (FinöV); CHF 6.4 billion from 2016-2025 (FABI); CHF 12.9 billion from 2025-2035 (FABI).</span></span></span></a></span> On a per-capita basis, it becomes even more apparent that this contributed to Switzerland’s high modal share. By comparison, Switzerland invested €440 per person in rail infrastructure in 2020, whereas other advanced European economies typically invested between €40 and €250 per capita (e.g., Germany invested €88 per capita).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c9738373-1567-48d6-98b9-21513f120eda"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c9738373-1567-48d6-98b9-21513f120eda" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Germany invests too little in rail infrastructure,” Allianz pro Schiene, August 2021, allianz-pro-schiene.de.</span></span></span></a></span> Switzerland’s high investment and commitment resulted in increased ridership and satisfaction (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/safe%20smart%20and%20green%20boosting%20european%20passenger%20rails%20modal%20share/svg-european-rail-exhibit-3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Lessons can be learned from the Swiss rail network." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/safe%20smart%20and%20green%20boosting%20european%20passenger%20rails%20modal%20share/svg-european-rail-exhibit-3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>What can companies and countries do now to concretely position themselves for growth in modal share? Investment is only one half of the equation. Stakeholders can make sure that three potential enablers are in place to ensure that investments lead to increased modal share.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Rebooting customer experience to bring back the magic of travel" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/rebooting%20customer%20experience%20to%20bring%20back%20the%20magic%20of%20travel/standard-skift-report.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Rebooting customer experience to bring back the magic of travel</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/rebooting-customer-experience-to-bring-back-the-magic-of-travel" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the report</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Three potential enablers to improve investment success</h2>
<p>There are three potential enablers that companies and countries may want to leverage to ensure that investments are successful and ultimately increase modal share: applying CAPEX excellence, enhancing digitization and analytics, and improving governance and incentives.</p>
<h3>Applying CAPEX excellence</h3>
<p>Some rail infrastructure projects may incur budget overruns or encounter delays, and this phenomenon is a Europe-wide issue. Overruns and delays are often caused by five challenges: financial complexity, planning difficulties, a complex stakeholder environment, procurement risks, and internal project-management challenges. Applying CAPEX excellence can mitigate these challenges. For instance, stakeholders can ensure that there is a structured process for value creation from origination to commission, by applying several techniques such as lean construction and integrated planning. They can also implement the right governance and monitoring systems to track the production pipeline, profitability, resource utilization, and physical progress.</p>
<p>Leveraging tools such as digital twins and five-dimensional building information modeling (5D BIM) can also help to optimize processes. 5D BIM is a digital representation of the physical and functional characteristics of a project. It allows users to create models that demonstrate how changes to materials, layout, square footage, and other design elements not only affect the appearance of a facility, but also the cost and schedule of construction.</p>
<p>These tools help to detect project deviation in construction accurately and timeously. They also offer features such as agile engineering, field virtualization, and advanced operations including incorporation of advanced analytics, big data, and automation.</p>
<p>Typically, CAPEX-excellence programs can realize savings that could be reinvested to increase modal share through other projects.</p>
<h3>Enhancing digitization and analytics</h3>
<p>Even though countries and companies understand the value of digitization and analytics, not all have actually put it at the forefront of their strategies. McKinsey’s Global Institute’s Industry Digitization Index provides evidence that the transportation and logistics industry shows relatively low levels of digitization.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6b5133a5-e4ba-40fd-9e39-04100d2077e0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6b5133a5-e4ba-40fd-9e39-04100d2077e0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/digital-america-a-tale-of-the-haves-and-have-mores">Digital America: A tale of the haves and have-mores</a>,” McKinsey Global Institute, December 1, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Rail companies could leverage digitization and analytics to improve performance in the following five areas:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Process optimization and asset management.</em> For instance, real-time fleet management and predictive maintenance can drastically improve efficiency and reliability. Companies have already started leveraging advanced analytics for predictive maintenance and construction planning. One European rail infrastructure provider reduced the number of trains affected by construction work by 10 percent through analytics-driven closure allocation.</li>
    <li><em>People management.</em> Digital performance management can create transparency around performance, and ultimately drive customer satisfaction. Companies can also use automated planning systems, for example to allocate shifts and tasks for maintenance workers, to increase predictability.</li>
    <li><em>Network strategy.</em> Companies can leverage advanced analytics and scenario modeling to create a holistic network design that can unlock economic potential and maximize timetable efficiency.</li>
    <li><em>User experience.</em> Companies can improve user experience through providing improved facilities, such as high-speed WiFi, or partnering with MaaS suppliers to provide door-to-door trip-manager apps that increase ease of use.</li>
    <li><em>Customer analytics, pricing, and optimized payments.</em> Companies can use analytics to effectively target customers through the right pricing schemes, and enable a seamless journey from a payment perspective. Rail companies can learn from their airline counterparts, particularly regarding how to target customers more effectively, increase user satisfaction, and reduce churn.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Improving governance and incentives</h3>
<p>Governance for rail-infrastructure projects may sometimes be characterized by low effectiveness in project steering and limited incentives to save costs, or inaccurate estimates, all leading to delays and cost overruns. Some issues could also center around under-resourcing, a limited focus on continuous improvement, a lack of transparency on progress and bottlenecks, and complex stakeholder management.</p>
<p>The following example illustrates the factors involved in setting incentives. In 2014, the modernization of the EU public procurement framework strengthened the concept of the Most Economically Advantageous Tender (MEAT) criteria when awarding contracts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0e7e7eb9-cd7c-4285-8af2-81514d531106"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0e7e7eb9-cd7c-4285-8af2-81514d531106" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anna Lupi, “The use of MEAT," Forum on Competitiveness of the European Rail Supply Industry, European Commission, October 5, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> MEAT takes into consideration aspects other than the lowest price, whereas price or cost criteria remain key factors that influence contract choice.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4406f630-abdc-4509-bb32-2883776d0d13"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4406f630-abdc-4509-bb32-2883776d0d13" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“MEAT principle: a more sustainable approach to public procurement for infrastructure,” Construction Project Europe, September 4, 2018, construction-products.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> Contracts could therefore consider quality-price ratios, in addition to costs, to ensure best value for money.</p>
<p>Good governance will involve a crisp definition of overall organization and project scope, detailed role descriptions and a precise team structure for each type of project, clear processes for how different units should work, explicit interaction and decision-making processes, as well as investment in capability building to sustain new, more agile ways of working. In addition to a strong governance setup, projects can benefit from rigorous control of financial metrics, and to make sure that transparent KPIs are in place.</p>
<h2>Optimizing modal share could benefit from international collaboration</h2>
<p>The European rail industry is well placed to deliver smart and green transportation. Funding is available for projects that will increase modal share and sustainability. However, improvements on a country-by-country basis could lead to suboptimal results. International collaboration can help achieve optimal results across the three dimensions of CAPEX excellence, digitization and analytics, and governance and incentives.</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>CAPEX excellence.</em> In the late 1990s, the construction of a key European freight corridor ran over time and over budget. Delays in construction, particularly of critical connections, led to decreased capacity, with fewer trains running than originally planned. In this instance, greater collaboration across countries could have led to increased project and investment efficiency.<br>
    <br>
    Pooling funds internationally and aligning planning between operators and authorities across countries can help support faster growth and greater cost and time efficiencies. The automobile industry provides a private-sector example of such an approach. In 2017, several automotive manufacturers created the joint venture IONITY to rapidly develop a high-power charging network for electric vehicles in Europe and enable growth in electric vehicle sales. IONITY also provides compatibility across vehicles, and an intuitive and consistent experience for customers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="29e4a0c3-199a-4a17-b019-0ae59470ebfb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="29e4a0c3-199a-4a17-b019-0ae59470ebfb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">IONITY website, ionity.eu.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Digitization and analytics.</em> As noted in McKinsey’s “<a href="/featured-insights/europe/digitizing-europes-railways-a-call-to-action">Digitizing Europe’s railways: a call to action</a>,” stakeholders may need to change the way the industry operates to accelerate the digitization of Europe’s railways. The pace of overall digital progress across Europe is slow, in ERMTS for example.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="562e29b2-be6a-465f-8277-9f4b63abd15d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="562e29b2-be6a-465f-8277-9f4b63abd15d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">European Rail Traffic Management System (ERMTS): ERMTS is the European standard for Automatic Train Protection (ATP) and command and control systems. It is a safety system that enforces compliance from trains with speed restrictions and signaling status. It creates an interoperable railway system in Europe.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, multiple rules regarding traffic operation still co-exist, and on the manufacturing front, original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) use different technology platforms. In other industries, players across the value chain combine their digitization efforts. For example, multiple premium-car OEMs use HERE Technologies, that provides mapping and location data, to combine their work on autonomous vehicles.<br>
    <br>
    The railway industry could choose to set itself a truly European ambition for example, a single digital infrastructure for Europe by 2050. This might help companies and countries reap the full benefits of digitization and analytics.</li>
    <li><em>Governance and incentives.</em> Companies and countries are sometimes incentivized on a national level, which may lead to regional inefficiencies, thereby increasing the costs of the system as a whole and negatively impacting the price of transit. For example, national standards are sometimes enforced on certification of rolling stock, leading to high costs and slow adoption. This raises the question of whether a train manufactured in France still requires an extensive certification process in Germany. In an optimal pan-European setting, regulation for certification (and other processes) that was set at a European level with sufficient trust and standardization among countries could help reduce such duplication of efforts.<br>
    <br>
    Greater international collaboration could help set the industry on a path of transformation, and ensure that each country’s investments yield optimal results.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The European railway industry has potential to significantly improve passenger rail’s modal share, but decision, action and cooperation are needed to make this a reality. There is clear momentum across countries to invest in rail as a sustainable, smart and safe means of transport, and there are examples of success for decision makers to learn from. Companies and national authorities could benefit from taking action now to evaluate the impact of their actions on modal share, collaborate across borders, and define a strategy towards a path of sustained rail growth.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Anselm Ott</strong> is a consultant in McKinsey’s Düsseldorf office; <strong><a href="/our-people/nicola-sandri">Nicola Sandri</a></strong> is a partner in the Milan office; and <strong>Luuk Speksnijder</strong> is an associate partner in the Amsterdam office, where <strong>Koen Wolfs</strong> is a consultant</p>
